column3: 3)	" My intentions in the field of civil rights have been spelled out in the Republican platform. I think we have to make progress first in the field of employment. And there we would give statutory authority to the Committee on Government Contracts
column4: which is an effective way of getting real progress made in this area
column5: since about one out of every four jobs is held by and is allotted by people who have government contracts. Certainly I think all of us agree that when anybody has a government contract
column6: certainly the money that is spent under that contract ought to be disbursed equally without regard to the race or creed or color of the individual who is to be employed. Second
column7: in the field of schools
column8: we believe that there should be provisions whereby the federal government would give assistance to those districts who do want to integrate their schools. That of course was rejected as was the government contracts provision by the special session of the Congress to - in which Mr. Kennedy was quite active. And then as far as other areas are concerned
column9: I think that we have to look to presidential leadership. And when I speak of presidential leadership
column10: I refer for example to our attitude on the sit-in strikes. Here we have a situation which causes all of us concern - causes us concern because of the denial of the rights of people to the equality which we think belongs to everybody. I have talked to Negro mothers. I've heard them explain - try to explain - how they tell their children how they can go into a store and buy a loaf of bread but then can't go into that store and sit at the counter and get a Coca Cola. This is wrong
column11: and we have to do something about it. So
column12: under the circumstances
column13: what do we do? Well what we do is what the Attorney-General of the United States did under the direction of the President: call in the owners of chain stores and get them to take action. Now there are other places where the executive can lead
column14: but let me just sum up by saying this: why do I talk every time I'm in the South on civil rights? Not because I am preaching to the people of the South because this isn't just a Southern problem; it's a Northern problem and a Western problem; it's a problem for all of us. I do it because it's the responsibility of leadership
column15: I do it because we have to solve this problem together. I do it right at this time particularly because when we have Khrushchev in this country - a man who has enslaved millions
column16: a man who has slaughtered thousands - we cannot continue to have a situation where he can point the finger at the United States of America and say that we are denying rights to our citizens. And so I say both the candidates and both the vice presidential candidates
column17: I would hope as well - including Senator Johnson - should talk on this issue at every opportunity.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Nixon hasn't discussed the two basic questions: what is going to be done and what will be his policy on implementing the Supreme Court decision of 1954? Giving aid to schools technically that are trying to carry out the decision is not the great question. Secondly
column3: what's he going to do to provide fair employment? He's been the head of the Committee on Government Contracts that's carried out two cases
column4: both in the District of Columbia. He has not indicated his support of an attempt to provide fair employment practices around the country
column5: so that everyone can get a job regardless of their race or color. Nor has he indicated that he will support Title Three
column6: which would give the Attorney General additional powers to protect Constitutional rights. These are the great questions: equality of education in school. About two percent of our population of white people are - is illiterate
column7: ten per cent of our colored population. Sixty to seventy percent of our colored children do not finish high school. These are the questions in these areas that the North and South
column8: East and West are entitled to know. What will be the leadership of the president in these areas to provide equality of opportunity for employment? Equality of opportunity in the field of housing
column9: which could be done on all federal supported housing by a stroke of the president's pen. What will be done to provide equality of education in all sections of the United States? Those are the questions to which the president must establish a moral tone and moral leadership. And I can assure you that if I'm elected president we will do so.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 3)	" My intentions in the field of civil rights have been spelled out in the Republican platform. I think we have to make progress first in the field of employment. And there we would give statutory authority to the Committee on Government Contracts
column4: which is an effective way of getting real progress made in this area
column5: since about one out of every four jobs is held by and is allotted by people who have government contracts. Certainly I think all of us agree that when anybody has a government contract
column6: certainly the money that is spent under that contract ought to be disbursed equally without regard to the race or creed or color of the individual who is to be employed. Second
column7: in the field of schools
column8: we believe that there should be provisions whereby the federal government would give assistance to those districts who do want to integrate their schools. That of course was rejected as was the government contracts provision by the special session of the Congress to - in which Mr. Kennedy was quite active. And then as far as other areas are concerned
column9: I think that we have to look to presidential leadership. And when I speak of presidential leadership
column10: I refer for example to our attitude on the sit-in strikes. Here we have a situation which causes all of us concern - causes us concern because of the denial of the rights of people to the equality which we think belongs to everybody. I have talked to Negro mothers. I've heard them explain - try to explain - how they tell their children how they can go into a store and buy a loaf of bread but then can't go into that store and sit at the counter and get a Coca Cola. This is wrong
column11: and we have to do something about it. So
column12: under the circumstances
column13: what do we do? Well what we do is what the Attorney-General of the United States did under the direction of the President: call in the owners of chain stores and get them to take action. Now there are other places where the executive can lead
column14: but let me just sum up by saying this: why do I talk every time I'm in the South on civil rights? Not because I am preaching to the people of the South because this isn't just a Southern problem; it's a Northern problem and a Western problem; it's a problem for all of us. I do it because it's the responsibility of leadership
column15: I do it because we have to solve this problem together. I do it right at this time particularly because when we have Khrushchev in this country - a man who has enslaved millions
column16: a man who has slaughtered thousands - we cannot continue to have a situation where he can point the finger at the United States of America and say that we are denying rights to our citizens. And so I say both the candidates and both the vice presidential candidates
column17: I would hope as well - including Senator Johnson - should talk on this issue at every opportunity.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Nixon hasn't discussed the two basic questions: what is going to be done and what will be his policy on implementing the Supreme Court decision of 1954? Giving aid to schools technically that are trying to carry out the decision is not the great question. Secondly
column3: what's he going to do to provide fair employment? He's been the head of the Committee on Government Contracts that's carried out two cases
column4: both in the District of Columbia. He has not indicated his support of an attempt to provide fair employment practices around the country
column5: so that everyone can get a job regardless of their race or color. Nor has he indicated that he will support Title Three
column6: which would give the Attorney General additional powers to protect Constitutional rights. These are the great questions: equality of education in school. About two percent of our population of white people are - is illiterate
column7: ten per cent of our colored population. Sixty to seventy percent of our colored children do not finish high school. These are the questions in these areas that the North and South
column8: East and West are entitled to know. What will be the leadership of the president in these areas to provide equality of opportunity for employment? Equality of opportunity in the field of housing
column9: which could be done on all federal supported housing by a stroke of the president's pen. What will be done to provide equality of education in all sections of the United States? Those are the questions to which the president must establish a moral tone and moral leadership. And I can assure you that if I'm elected president we will do so.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 3)	" My intentions in the field of civil rights have been spelled out in the Republican platform. I think we have to make progress first in the field of employment. And there we would give statutory authority to the Committee on Government Contracts
column4: which is an effective way of getting real progress made in this area
column5: since about one out of every four jobs is held by and is allotted by people who have government contracts. Certainly I think all of us agree that when anybody has a government contract
column6: certainly the money that is spent under that contract ought to be disbursed equally without regard to the race or creed or color of the individual who is to be employed. Second
column7: in the field of schools
column8: we believe that there should be provisions whereby the federal government would give assistance to those districts who do want to integrate their schools. That of course was rejected as was the government contracts provision by the special session of the Congress to - in which Mr. Kennedy was quite active. And then as far as other areas are concerned
column9: I think that we have to look to presidential leadership. And when I speak of presidential leadership
column10: I refer for example to our attitude on the sit-in strikes. Here we have a situation which causes all of us concern - causes us concern because of the denial of the rights of people to the equality which we think belongs to everybody. I have talked to Negro mothers. I've heard them explain - try to explain - how they tell their children how they can go into a store and buy a loaf of bread but then can't go into that store and sit at the counter and get a Coca Cola. This is wrong
column11: and we have to do something about it. So
column12: under the circumstances
column13: what do we do? Well what we do is what the Attorney-General of the United States did under the direction of the President: call in the owners of chain stores and get them to take action. Now there are other places where the executive can lead
column14: but let me just sum up by saying this: why do I talk every time I'm in the South on civil rights? Not because I am preaching to the people of the South because this isn't just a Southern problem; it's a Northern problem and a Western problem; it's a problem for all of us. I do it because it's the responsibility of leadership
column15: I do it because we have to solve this problem together. I do it right at this time particularly because when we have Khrushchev in this country - a man who has enslaved millions
column16: a man who has slaughtered thousands - we cannot continue to have a situation where he can point the finger at the United States of America and say that we are denying rights to our citizens. And so I say both the candidates and both the vice presidential candidates
column17: I would hope as well - including Senator Johnson - should talk on this issue at every opportunity.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Nixon hasn't discussed the two basic questions: what is going to be done and what will be his policy on implementing the Supreme Court decision of 1954? Giving aid to schools technically that are trying to carry out the decision is not the great question. Secondly
column3: what's he going to do to provide fair employment? He's been the head of the Committee on Government Contracts that's carried out two cases
column4: both in the District of Columbia. He has not indicated his support of an attempt to provide fair employment practices around the country
column5: so that everyone can get a job regardless of their race or color. Nor has he indicated that he will support Title Three
column6: which would give the Attorney General additional powers to protect Constitutional rights. These are the great questions: equality of education in school. About two percent of our population of white people are - is illiterate
column7: ten per cent of our colored population. Sixty to seventy percent of our colored children do not finish high school. These are the questions in these areas that the North and South
column8: East and West are entitled to know. What will be the leadership of the president in these areas to provide equality of opportunity for employment? Equality of opportunity in the field of housing
column9: which could be done on all federal supported housing by a stroke of the president's pen. What will be done to provide equality of education in all sections of the United States? Those are the questions to which the president must establish a moral tone and moral leadership. And I can assure you that if I'm elected president we will do so.

column13: what do we do? Well what we do is what the Attorney-General of the United States did under the direction of the President: call in the owners of chain stores and get them to take action. Now there are other places where the executive can lead
column14: but let me just sum up by saying this: why do I talk every time I'm in the South on civil rights? Not because I am preaching to the people of the South because this isn't just a Southern problem; it's a Northern problem and a Western problem; it's a problem for all of us. I do it because it's the responsibility of leadership
column15: I do it because we have to solve this problem together. I do it right at this time particularly because when we have Khrushchev in this country - a man who has enslaved millions
column16: a man who has slaughtered thousands - we cannot continue to have a situation where he can point the finger at the United States of America and say that we are denying rights to our citizens. And so I say both the candidates and both the vice presidential candidates
column17: I would hope as well - including Senator Johnson - should talk on this issue at every opportunity.

column1: Well
column2: Mr. Nixon hasn't discussed the two basic questions: what is going to be done and what will be his policy on implementing the Supreme Court decision of 1954? Giving aid to schools technically that are trying to carry out the decision is not the great question. Secondly
column3: what's he going to do to provide fair employment? He's been the head of the Committee on Government Contracts that's carried out two cases
column4: both in the District of Columbia. He has not indicated his support of an attempt to provide fair employment practices around the country
column5: so that everyone can get a job regardless of their race or color. Nor has he indicated that he will support Title Three
column6: which would give the Attorney General additional powers to protect Constitutional rights. These are the great questions: equality of education in school. About two percent of our population of white people are - is illiterate
column7: ten per cent of our colored population. Sixty to seventy percent of our colored children do not finish high school. These are the questions in these areas that the North and South
column8: East and West are entitled to know. What will be the leadership of the president in these areas to provide equality of opportunity for employment? Equality of opportunity in the field of housing
column9: which could be done on all federal supported housing by a stroke of the president's pen. What will be done to provide equality of education in all sections of the United States? Those are the questions to which the president must establish a moral tone and moral leadership. And I can assure you that if I'm elected president we will do so.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 4)	" Well let me say that I think that the president operates in a number of different areas. First
column4: as a legislative leader. And as I just said that I believe that the passage of the so-called Title Three
column5: which gives the Attorney General the power to protect Constitutional rights in those cases where it's not possible for the person involved to bring the suit. Secondly
column6: as an executive leader. There have been only six cases brought by this Attorney General under the voting bill passed in 1957 and the voting bill passed in 1960. The right to vote is basic. I do not believe that this Administration has implemented those bills which represent the will of the majority of the Congress on two occasions with vigor. Thirdly
column7: I don't believe that the government contracts division is operated with vigor. Everyone who does business with the government should have the opportunity to make sure that they do not practice discrimination in their hiring. And that's in all sections of the United States. And then fourthly
column8: as a moral leader. There is a very strong moral basis for this concept of equality of opportunity. We are in a very difficult time. We need all the talent we can get. We sit on a conspicuous stage. We are a goldfish bowl before the world. We have to practice what we preach. We set a very high standard for ourselves. The Communists do not. They set a low standard of materialism. We preach in the Declaration of Independence and in the Constitution
column9: in the statement of our greatest leaders
column10: we preach very high standards; and if we're not going to be s- charged before the world with hypocrisy we have to meet those standards. I believe the president of the United States should indicate it. Now lastly
column11: I believe in the case of Little Rock. I would have hoped that the president of the United States would have been possible for him to indicate it clearly that uh - the Supreme Court decision was going to be carried out. I would have hoped that it would have been possible to use marshals to do so. But it wou- uh - evidently uh - under the handling of the case it was not. I would hope an incident like that would not happen. I think if the president is responsible
column12: if he consults with those involved
column13: if he makes it clear that the Supreme Court decision is going to be carried out in a way that the Supreme Court planned - with deliberate speed - then in my judgment
column14: providing he's behind action
column15: I believe we can make uh - progress. Now the present Administration - the President - has said - never indicated what he thought of the 1954 decision. Unless the president speaks
column16: then of course uh - the country doesn't speak
column17: and Franklin Roosevelt said: ""The pre - uh - the presidency of the United States is above all a place of moral leadership."" And I believe on this great moral issue he should speak out and give his views clearly.

column1: Senator Kennedy has expressed some hopes in this field
column2: hopes which I think all Americans would share who want some problem - some progress in this area. But let's look at the performance. When he selected his vice presidential running mate
column3: he selected a man who had voted against most of these proposals and who opposes them at the present time. Let me s- look also at what I did. I selected a man who stands with me in this field and who will talk with me and work with me on it. Now the Senator referred to the Committee on Government Contracts. And yet that very committee of which I am chairman has been handicapped by the fact that we have not had adequate funds; we have not had adequate powers; we haven't had an adequate staff. Now in the special session of Congress and also in the session that preceded it
column4: the Democratic Congress - in which there's a two-to-one Democratic majority - was asked by the President to give us the funds and give us the power to do a job and they did nothing at all
column5: And in the special session in which Senator Kennedy was calling the signals
column6: along with Senator Johnson
column7: they turned it down and he himself voted against giving us the powers despite the fact that the bill had already been considered before
column8: that it already had hearings on
column9: and the Congress already knew what it had before it. All that I can say is this: what we need here are not just high hopes. What we need is action. And in the field of executive leadership
column10: I can say that I believe it's essential that the president of the United States not only set the tone but he also must lead; he must act as he talks.

column11: ""Thirdly
column12: I don't believe that the government contracts division is operated with vigor.""

column14: ""And that's in all sections of the United States.""
column15: 'And then fourthly
column16: as a moral leader.'

column18: 'We are in a very difficult time.'
column19: 'We need all the talent we can get.'
column20: 'We sit on a conspicuous stage.'
column21: 'We are a goldfish bowl before the world.'
column22: 'We have to practice what we preach.'
column23: 'We set a very high standard for ourselves.'
column24: 'The Communists do not.'
column25: 'They set a low standard of materialism.'

column28: we preach very high standards; and if we're not going to be s- charged before the world with hypocrisy we have to meet those standards.""
column29: 'I believe the president of the United States should indicate it.'
column30: 'Now lastly
column31: I believe in the case of Little Rock.'
column32: 'I would have hoped that the president of the United States would have been possible for him to indicate it clearly that uh - the Supreme Court decision was going to be carried out.'
column33: 'I would have hoped that it would have been possible to use marshals to do so.'

column35: 'I would hope an incident like that would not happen.'

column38: if he makes it clear that the Supreme Court decision is going to be carried out in a way that the Supreme Court planned - with deliberate speed - then in my judgment

column41: 'Now the present Administration - the President - has said - never indicated what he thought of the 1954 decision.'

column43: then of course uh - the country doesn\'t speak
column44: and Franklin Roosevelt said: ""The pre - uh - the presidency of the United States is above all a place of moral leadership.""'

column49: 'When he selected his vice presidential running mate

column52: 'I selected a man who stands with me in this field and who will talk with me and work with me on it.'

column57: And in the special session in which Senator Kennedy was calling the signals
column59: they turned it down and he himself voted against giving us the powers despite the fact that the bill had already been considered before
column60: that it already had hearings on
column61: and the Congress already knew what it had before it.""
column62: 'All that I can say is this: what we need here are not just high hopes.'

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 4)	" Well let me say that I think that the president operates in a number of different areas. First
column4: as a legislative leader. And as I just said that I believe that the passage of the so-called Title Three
column5: which gives the Attorney General the power to protect Constitutional rights in those cases where it's not possible for the person involved to bring the suit. Secondly
column6: as an executive leader. There have been only six cases brought by this Attorney General under the voting bill passed in 1957 and the voting bill passed in 1960. The right to vote is basic. I do not believe that this Administration has implemented those bills which represent the will of the majority of the Congress on two occasions with vigor. Thirdly
column7: I don't believe that the government contracts division is operated with vigor. Everyone who does business with the government should have the opportunity to make sure that they do not practice discrimination in their hiring. And that's in all sections of the United States. And then fourthly
column8: as a moral leader. There is a very strong moral basis for this concept of equality of opportunity. We are in a very difficult time. We need all the talent we can get. We sit on a conspicuous stage. We are a goldfish bowl before the world. We have to practice what we preach. We set a very high standard for ourselves. The Communists do not. They set a low standard of materialism. We preach in the Declaration of Independence and in the Constitution
column9: in the statement of our greatest leaders
column10: we preach very high standards; and if we're not going to be s- charged before the world with hypocrisy we have to meet those standards. I believe the president of the United States should indicate it. Now lastly
column11: I believe in the case of Little Rock. I would have hoped that the president of the United States would have been possible for him to indicate it clearly that uh - the Supreme Court decision was going to be carried out. I would have hoped that it would have been possible to use marshals to do so. But it wou- uh - evidently uh - under the handling of the case it was not. I would hope an incident like that would not happen. I think if the president is responsible
column12: if he consults with those involved
column13: if he makes it clear that the Supreme Court decision is going to be carried out in a way that the Supreme Court planned - with deliberate speed - then in my judgment
column14: providing he's behind action
column15: I believe we can make uh - progress. Now the present Administration - the President - has said - never indicated what he thought of the 1954 decision. Unless the president speaks
column16: then of course uh - the country doesn't speak
column17: and Franklin Roosevelt said: ""The pre - uh - the presidency of the United States is above all a place of moral leadership."" And I believe on this great moral issue he should speak out and give his views clearly.

column1: Senator Kennedy has expressed some hopes in this field
column2: hopes which I think all Americans would share who want some problem - some progress in this area. But let's look at the performance. When he selected his vice presidential running mate
column3: he selected a man who had voted against most of these proposals and who opposes them at the present time. Let me s- look also at what I did. I selected a man who stands with me in this field and who will talk with me and work with me on it. Now the Senator referred to the Committee on Government Contracts. And yet that very committee of which I am chairman has been handicapped by the fact that we have not had adequate funds; we have not had adequate powers; we haven't had an adequate staff. Now in the special session of Congress and also in the session that preceded it
column4: the Democratic Congress - in which there's a two-to-one Democratic majority - was asked by the President to give us the funds and give us the power to do a job and they did nothing at all
column5: And in the special session in which Senator Kennedy was calling the signals
column6: along with Senator Johnson
column7: they turned it down and he himself voted against giving us the powers despite the fact that the bill had already been considered before
column8: that it already had hearings on
column9: and the Congress already knew what it had before it. All that I can say is this: what we need here are not just high hopes. What we need is action. And in the field of executive leadership
column10: I can say that I believe it's essential that the president of the United States not only set the tone but he also must lead; he must act as he talks.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 4)	" Well let me say that I think that the president operates in a number of different areas. First
column4: as a legislative leader. And as I just said that I believe that the passage of the so-called Title Three
column5: which gives the Attorney General the power to protect Constitutional rights in those cases where it's not possible for the person involved to bring the suit. Secondly
column6: as an executive leader. There have been only six cases brought by this Attorney General under the voting bill passed in 1957 and the voting bill passed in 1960. The right to vote is basic. I do not believe that this Administration has implemented those bills which represent the will of the majority of the Congress on two occasions with vigor. Thirdly
column7: I don't believe that the government contracts division is operated with vigor. Everyone who does business with the government should have the opportunity to make sure that they do not practice discrimination in their hiring. And that's in all sections of the United States. And then fourthly
column8: as a moral leader. There is a very strong moral basis for this concept of equality of opportunity. We are in a very difficult time. We need all the talent we can get. We sit on a conspicuous stage. We are a goldfish bowl before the world. We have to practice what we preach. We set a very high standard for ourselves. The Communists do not. They set a low standard of materialism. We preach in the Declaration of Independence and in the Constitution
column9: in the statement of our greatest leaders
column10: we preach very high standards; and if we're not going to be s- charged before the world with hypocrisy we have to meet those standards. I believe the president of the United States should indicate it. Now lastly
column11: I believe in the case of Little Rock. I would have hoped that the president of the United States would have been possible for him to indicate it clearly that uh - the Supreme Court decision was going to be carried out. I would have hoped that it would have been possible to use marshals to do so. But it wou- uh - evidently uh - under the handling of the case it was not. I would hope an incident like that would not happen. I think if the president is responsible
column12: if he consults with those involved
column13: if he makes it clear that the Supreme Court decision is going to be carried out in a way that the Supreme Court planned - with deliberate speed - then in my judgment
column14: providing he's behind action
column15: I believe we can make uh - progress. Now the present Administration - the President - has said - never indicated what he thought of the 1954 decision. Unless the president speaks
column16: then of course uh - the country doesn't speak
column17: and Franklin Roosevelt said: ""The pre - uh - the presidency of the United States is above all a place of moral leadership."" And I believe on this great moral issue he should speak out and give his views clearly.

column1: Senator Kennedy has expressed some hopes in this field
column2: hopes which I think all Americans would share who want some problem - some progress in this area. But let's look at the performance. When he selected his vice presidential running mate
column3: he selected a man who had voted against most of these proposals and who opposes them at the present time. Let me s- look also at what I did. I selected a man who stands with me in this field and who will talk with me and work with me on it. Now the Senator referred to the Committee on Government Contracts. And yet that very committee of which I am chairman has been handicapped by the fact that we have not had adequate funds; we have not had adequate powers; we haven't had an adequate staff. Now in the special session of Congress and also in the session that preceded it
column4: the Democratic Congress - in which there's a two-to-one Democratic majority - was asked by the President to give us the funds and give us the power to do a job and they did nothing at all
column5: And in the special session in which Senator Kennedy was calling the signals
column6: along with Senator Johnson
column7: they turned it down and he himself voted against giving us the powers despite the fact that the bill had already been considered before
column8: that it already had hearings on
column9: and the Congress already knew what it had before it. All that I can say is this: what we need here are not just high hopes. What we need is action. And in the field of executive leadership
column10: I can say that I believe it's essential that the president of the United States not only set the tone but he also must lead; he must act as he talks.

column1: And in the special session in which Senator Kennedy was calling the signals, along with Senator Johnson, they turned it down and he himself voted against giving us the powers despite the fact that the bill had already been considered before, that it already had hearings on, and the Congress already knew what it had before it. column2: '07Oct'
column3: 5)	" Mr. Morgan
column4: no matter how well we're doing in the cold war
column5: we're not doing as well as we should. And that will always be the case as long as the Communists are on the international scene
column6: in the aggressive tac- uh - tendencies that they presently are following. Now as far as the present situation is concerned
column7: I think it's time that we nail a few of these distortions about the United States that have been put out. First of all
column8: we hear that our prestige is at an all-time low. Senator Kennedy has been hitting that point over and over again. I would suggest that after Premier Kush- Khrushchev's uh - performance in the United Nations
column9: compared with President Eisenhower's eloquent speech
column10: that at the present time Communist prestige in the world is at an all-time low and American prestige is at an all-time high. Now that
column11: of course
column12: is just one factor
column13: but it's a significant one. When we look
column14: for example
column15: at the vote on the Congo. We were on one side; they were on the other side. What happened? There were seventy votes for our position and none for theirs. Look at the votes in the United Nations over the past seven and a half years. That's a test of prestige. Every time the United States has been an one side and they've been on the other side
column16: our position has been sustained. Now looking to what we ought to do in the future. In this cold war we have to recognize where it is being fought and then we have to develop programs to deal with it. It's being fought primarily in Asia
column17: in Africa
column18: and in Latin America. What do we need? What tools do we need to fight us? Well we need
column19: for example
column20: economic assistance; we need technical assistance; we need exchange; we need programs of diplomatic and other character which will be effective in that area. Now Senator Kennedy a moment ago referred to the fact that there was not an adequate Voice of America program for Latin America. I'd like to point out that in the last six years
column21: the Democratic Congresses
column22: of which he'd been a member
column23: have cut twenty million dollars off of the Voice of America programs. They also have cut four billion dollars off of mutual security in these last six years. They also have cut two billion dollars off of defense. Now when they talk about our record here
column24: it is well that they recognize that they have to stand up for their record as well. So let me summarize by saying this: I'm not satisfied with what we're doing in the cold war because I believe we have to step up our activities and launch an offensive for the minds and hearts and souls of men. It must be economic; it must be technological; above all it must be ideological. But we've got to get help from the Congress in order to do this.

column1: Of course Mr. Nixon is wholly inaccurate when he says that the Congress has not provided more funds in fact than the President recommended for national defense. Nineteen fifty-three we tried to put an appropriation of five billion dollars for our defenses. I was responsible for the amendment with Senator Monroney in 1954 to strengthen our ground forces. The Congress of the United States appropriated six hundred and seventy-seven million dollars mare than the President was willing to use up till a week ago. Secondly
column2: on the question of our position in the United Nations. We all know about the vote held this week - of the five neutralists - and it was generally regarded as a defeat for the United States. Thirdly
column4: there were only seven votes in favor of the admission of Red China into the United Nations. Last year there were twenty-nine and tomorrow when the preliminary vote is held you will see a strengthening of that position or very closely to it. We have not maintained our position and our prestige. A Gallup Poll taken in February of this year asking the - in eight out of nine countries - they asked the people
column5: who do they think would be ahead by 1970 militarily and scientifically
column6: and a majority in eight of the nine countries said the Soviet Union would be by 1970. Governor Rockefeller has been far more critical in June of our position in the world than I have been. The Rockefeller Brothers report
column7: General Ridgway
column8: General Gavin
column9: the Gaither Report
column10: various reports of Congressional committees all indicate that the relative strength of the p- United States both militarily
column11: politically
column12: psychologically
column13: and scientifically and industrially - the relative strength of the so- of United States compared to that of the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists together - has deteriorated in the last eight years and we should know it
column14: and the American people should be told the facts.

column1: And that will always be the case as long as the Communists are on the international scene, in the aggressive tac- uh - tendencies that they presently are following. column2: '07Oct'
column3: 5)	" Mr. Morgan
column4: no matter how well we're doing in the cold war
column5: we're not doing as well as we should. And that will always be the case as long as the Communists are on the international scene
column6: in the aggressive tac- uh - tendencies that they presently are following. Now as far as the present situation is concerned
column7: I think it's time that we nail a few of these distortions about the United States that have been put out. First of all
column8: we hear that our prestige is at an all-time low. Senator Kennedy has been hitting that point over and over again. I would suggest that after Premier Kush- Khrushchev's uh - performance in the United Nations
column9: compared with President Eisenhower's eloquent speech
column10: that at the present time Communist prestige in the world is at an all-time low and American prestige is at an all-time high. Now that
column11: of course
column12: is just one factor
column13: but it's a significant one. When we look
column14: for example
column15: at the vote on the Congo. We were on one side; they were on the other side. What happened? There were seventy votes for our position and none for theirs. Look at the votes in the United Nations over the past seven and a half years. That's a test of prestige. Every time the United States has been an one side and they've been on the other side
column16: our position has been sustained. Now looking to what we ought to do in the future. In this cold war we have to recognize where it is being fought and then we have to develop programs to deal with it. It's being fought primarily in Asia
column17: in Africa
column18: and in Latin America. What do we need? What tools do we need to fight us? Well we need
column19: for example
column20: economic assistance; we need technical assistance; we need exchange; we need programs of diplomatic and other character which will be effective in that area. Now Senator Kennedy a moment ago referred to the fact that there was not an adequate Voice of America program for Latin America. I'd like to point out that in the last six years
column21: the Democratic Congresses
column22: of which he'd been a member
column23: have cut twenty million dollars off of the Voice of America programs. They also have cut four billion dollars off of mutual security in these last six years. They also have cut two billion dollars off of defense. Now when they talk about our record here
column24: it is well that they recognize that they have to stand up for their record as well. So let me summarize by saying this: I'm not satisfied with what we're doing in the cold war because I believe we have to step up our activities and launch an offensive for the minds and hearts and souls of men. It must be economic; it must be technological; above all it must be ideological. But we've got to get help from the Congress in order to do this.

column1: Of course Mr. Nixon is wholly inaccurate when he says that the Congress has not provided more funds in fact than the President recommended for national defense. Nineteen fifty-three we tried to put an appropriation of five billion dollars for our defenses. I was responsible for the amendment with Senator Monroney in 1954 to strengthen our ground forces. The Congress of the United States appropriated six hundred and seventy-seven million dollars mare than the President was willing to use up till a week ago. Secondly
column2: on the question of our position in the United Nations. We all know about the vote held this week - of the five neutralists - and it was generally regarded as a defeat for the United States. Thirdly
column4: there were only seven votes in favor of the admission of Red China into the United Nations. Last year there were twenty-nine and tomorrow when the preliminary vote is held you will see a strengthening of that position or very closely to it. We have not maintained our position and our prestige. A Gallup Poll taken in February of this year asking the - in eight out of nine countries - they asked the people
column5: who do they think would be ahead by 1970 militarily and scientifically
column6: and a majority in eight of the nine countries said the Soviet Union would be by 1970. Governor Rockefeller has been far more critical in June of our position in the world than I have been. The Rockefeller Brothers report
column7: General Ridgway
column8: General Gavin
column9: the Gaither Report
column10: various reports of Congressional committees all indicate that the relative strength of the p- United States both militarily
column11: politically
column12: psychologically
column13: and scientifically and industrially - the relative strength of the so- of United States compared to that of the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists together - has deteriorated in the last eight years and we should know it
column14: and the American people should be told the facts.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 5)	" Mr. Morgan
column4: no matter how well we're doing in the cold war
column5: we're not doing as well as we should. And that will always be the case as long as the Communists are on the international scene
column6: in the aggressive tac- uh - tendencies that they presently are following. Now as far as the present situation is concerned
column7: I think it's time that we nail a few of these distortions about the United States that have been put out. First of all
column8: we hear that our prestige is at an all-time low. Senator Kennedy has been hitting that point over and over again. I would suggest that after Premier Kush- Khrushchev's uh - performance in the United Nations
column9: compared with President Eisenhower's eloquent speech
column10: that at the present time Communist prestige in the world is at an all-time low and American prestige is at an all-time high. Now that
column11: of course
column12: is just one factor
column13: but it's a significant one. When we look
column14: for example
column15: at the vote on the Congo. We were on one side; they were on the other side. What happened? There were seventy votes for our position and none for theirs. Look at the votes in the United Nations over the past seven and a half years. That's a test of prestige. Every time the United States has been an one side and they've been on the other side
column16: our position has been sustained. Now looking to what we ought to do in the future. In this cold war we have to recognize where it is being fought and then we have to develop programs to deal with it. It's being fought primarily in Asia
column17: in Africa
column18: and in Latin America. What do we need? What tools do we need to fight us? Well we need
column19: for example
column20: economic assistance; we need technical assistance; we need exchange; we need programs of diplomatic and other character which will be effective in that area. Now Senator Kennedy a moment ago referred to the fact that there was not an adequate Voice of America program for Latin America. I'd like to point out that in the last six years
column21: the Democratic Congresses
column22: of which he'd been a member
column23: have cut twenty million dollars off of the Voice of America programs. They also have cut four billion dollars off of mutual security in these last six years. They also have cut two billion dollars off of defense. Now when they talk about our record here
column24: it is well that they recognize that they have to stand up for their record as well. So let me summarize by saying this: I'm not satisfied with what we're doing in the cold war because I believe we have to step up our activities and launch an offensive for the minds and hearts and souls of men. It must be economic; it must be technological; above all it must be ideological. But we've got to get help from the Congress in order to do this.

column1: Of course Mr. Nixon is wholly inaccurate when he says that the Congress has not provided more funds in fact than the President recommended for national defense. Nineteen fifty-three we tried to put an appropriation of five billion dollars for our defenses. I was responsible for the amendment with Senator Monroney in 1954 to strengthen our ground forces. The Congress of the United States appropriated six hundred and seventy-seven million dollars mare than the President was willing to use up till a week ago. Secondly
column2: on the question of our position in the United Nations. We all know about the vote held this week - of the five neutralists - and it was generally regarded as a defeat for the United States. Thirdly
column4: there were only seven votes in favor of the admission of Red China into the United Nations. Last year there were twenty-nine and tomorrow when the preliminary vote is held you will see a strengthening of that position or very closely to it. We have not maintained our position and our prestige. A Gallup Poll taken in February of this year asking the - in eight out of nine countries - they asked the people
column5: who do they think would be ahead by 1970 militarily and scientifically
column6: and a majority in eight of the nine countries said the Soviet Union would be by 1970. Governor Rockefeller has been far more critical in June of our position in the world than I have been. The Rockefeller Brothers report
column7: General Ridgway
column8: General Gavin
column9: the Gaither Report
column10: various reports of Congressional committees all indicate that the relative strength of the p- United States both militarily
column11: politically
column12: psychologically
column13: and scientifically and industrially - the relative strength of the so- of United States compared to that of the Soviet Union and the Chinese Communists together - has deteriorated in the last eight years and we should know it
column14: and the American people should be told the facts.

column1: Now when they talk about our record here, it is well that they recognize that they have to stand up for their record as well. column2: '07Oct'
column3: 6)	" Yes. We have been wholly indifferent to Latin America until the last few months. The program that was put forward this summer
column4: after we broke off the sugar quota with Cuba
column5: really was done because we wanted to get through the O.A.S. meeting a condemnation of Russian infiltration of Cuba. And therefore we passed an authorization - not an aid bill - which was the first time
column6: really
column7: since the Inter-American Bank which was founded a year ago was developed
column8: that we really have looked at the needs of Latin America; that we have associated ourselves with those people. Secondly
column9: I believe that in the ca- that it's far better for the United States
column10: instead of concentrating our aid
column11: particularly in the underdeveloped world
column12: on surplus military equipment - we poured three hundred million dollars of surplus military equipment into Laos. We paid more military aid
column13: more aid into Laos po- per - per person than in any country in the world and we ought to know now that Laos is moving from neutralism in the direction of the Communists. I believe instead of doing that
column14: we should concentrate our aid in long-term loans which these people can pay back either in hard money or in local currency. This permits them to maintain their self-respect. It permits us to make sure that the projects which are invested in are going to produce greater wealth. And I believe that in cases of India and Africa and Latin America that this is where our emphasis should be. I would strengthen the Development Loan Fund. And Senator Fulbright
column15: Senator Humphrey and I tried to do that. We tried to provide an appropriation of a billion and a half for five years
column16: on a long-term loan basis
column17: which this Administration opposed. And unless we're ready to carry out programs like that in the sixties
column18: this battle for economic survival which these people are waging are going to be lost. And if India should lose her battle
column19: with thirty-five per cent of the people of the underdeveloped world within her borders
column20: then I believe that the balance of power could move against us. I think the United States can afford to do these things. I think that we could not afford not to do these things. This goes to our survival. And here in a country which if it is moving ahead
column21: if it's developing its economy to the fullest - which we are not now - in my judgment
column22: we'll have the resources to meet our military commitments and also our commitments overseas. I believe it's essential that we do it because in the next ten years the balance of power is going to begin to move in the world from one direction or another - towards us or towards the Communists - and unless we begin to identify ourselves not only with the anti-Communist fight
column23: but also with the fight against poverty and hunger
column24: these people are going to begin to turn to the Communists as an example. I believe we can do it. If we build our economy the way we should
column25: we can afford to do these things and we must do it.

column1: Senator Kennedy has put a great deal of stress on the necessity for economic assistance. This is important. But it's also tremendously important to bear in mind that when you pour in money without pouring in technical assistance at w- as well
column2: that you have a disastrous situation. We need to step up exchange; we need to step up technical assistance so that trained people in these newly developing countries can operate the economies. We also have to have in mind something else with regard to this whole situation in the world
column3: and that is: that as America moves forward
column4: we not only must think in terms of fighting Communism
column5: but we must also think primarily in terms of the interests of these countries. We must associate ourselves with their aspirations. We must let them know that the great American ideals - of independence
column6: of the right of people to be free
column7: and of the right to progress - that these are ideals that belong not to ourselves alone
column8: but they belong to everybody. This we must get across to the world. And we can't do it unless we do have adequate funds for
column9: for example
column10: information which has been cut by the Congress
column11: adequate funds for technical assistance. The other point that I would make with regard to economic assistance and technical assistance is that the United States must not rest its case here alone. This is primarily an ideological battle - a battle for the minds and the hearts and the souls of men. We must not meet the Communists purely in the field of gross atheistic materialism. We must stand for our ideals.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 6)	" Yes. We have been wholly indifferent to Latin America until the last few months. The program that was put forward this summer
column4: after we broke off the sugar quota with Cuba
column5: really was done because we wanted to get through the O.A.S. meeting a condemnation of Russian infiltration of Cuba. And therefore we passed an authorization - not an aid bill - which was the first time
column6: really
column7: since the Inter-American Bank which was founded a year ago was developed
column8: that we really have looked at the needs of Latin America; that we have associated ourselves with those people. Secondly
column9: I believe that in the ca- that it's far better for the United States
column10: instead of concentrating our aid
column11: particularly in the underdeveloped world
column12: on surplus military equipment - we poured three hundred million dollars of surplus military equipment into Laos. We paid more military aid
column13: more aid into Laos po- per - per person than in any country in the world and we ought to know now that Laos is moving from neutralism in the direction of the Communists. I believe instead of doing that
column14: we should concentrate our aid in long-term loans which these people can pay back either in hard money or in local currency. This permits them to maintain their self-respect. It permits us to make sure that the projects which are invested in are going to produce greater wealth. And I believe that in cases of India and Africa and Latin America that this is where our emphasis should be. I would strengthen the Development Loan Fund. And Senator Fulbright
column15: Senator Humphrey and I tried to do that. We tried to provide an appropriation of a billion and a half for five years
column16: on a long-term loan basis
column17: which this Administration opposed. And unless we're ready to carry out programs like that in the sixties
column18: this battle for economic survival which these people are waging are going to be lost. And if India should lose her battle
column19: with thirty-five per cent of the people of the underdeveloped world within her borders
column20: then I believe that the balance of power could move against us. I think the United States can afford to do these things. I think that we could not afford not to do these things. This goes to our survival. And here in a country which if it is moving ahead
column21: if it's developing its economy to the fullest - which we are not now - in my judgment
column22: we'll have the resources to meet our military commitments and also our commitments overseas. I believe it's essential that we do it because in the next ten years the balance of power is going to begin to move in the world from one direction or another - towards us or towards the Communists - and unless we begin to identify ourselves not only with the anti-Communist fight
column23: but also with the fight against poverty and hunger
column24: these people are going to begin to turn to the Communists as an example. I believe we can do it. If we build our economy the way we should
column25: we can afford to do these things and we must do it.

column1: Senator Kennedy has put a great deal of stress on the necessity for economic assistance. This is important. But it's also tremendously important to bear in mind that when you pour in money without pouring in technical assistance at w- as well
column2: that you have a disastrous situation. We need to step up exchange; we need to step up technical assistance so that trained people in these newly developing countries can operate the economies. We also have to have in mind something else with regard to this whole situation in the world
column3: and that is: that as America moves forward
column4: we not only must think in terms of fighting Communism
column5: but we must also think primarily in terms of the interests of these countries. We must associate ourselves with their aspirations. We must let them know that the great American ideals - of independence
column6: of the right of people to be free
column7: and of the right to progress - that these are ideals that belong not to ourselves alone
column8: but they belong to everybody. This we must get across to the world. And we can't do it unless we do have adequate funds for
column9: for example
column10: information which has been cut by the Congress
column11: adequate funds for technical assistance. The other point that I would make with regard to economic assistance and technical assistance is that the United States must not rest its case here alone. This is primarily an ideological battle - a battle for the minds and the hearts and the souls of men. We must not meet the Communists purely in the field of gross atheistic materialism. We must stand for our ideals.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 7)	" To combat unemployment we first must concentrate on the very areas to which you refer - the so-called depressed areas. Now in the last Congress - the special session of the Congress - there was a bill: one by the President
column4: one by Senator Kennedy and members of his party. Now the bill that the President had submitted would have provided more aid for those areas that really need it - areas like Scranton and Wilkes-Barre and the areas of West Virginia - than the ones that Senator Kennedy was supporting. On the other hand we found that the bill got into the legislative difficulties and consequently no action was taken. So point one
column5: at the highest priority we must get a bill for depressed areas through the next Congress. I have made recommendations on that and I have discussed them previously and I will spell them out further in the campaign. Second
column6: as we consider this problem of unemployment
column7: we have to realize where it is. In analyzing the figures we will find that our unemployment exists among the older citizens; it exists also among those who are inadequately trained; that is
column8: those who do not have an adequate opportunity for education. It also exists among minority groups. If we're going to combat unemployment
column9: then
column10: we have to do a better job in these areas. That's why I have a program for education
column11: a program in the case of equal job opportunities
column12: and one that would also deal with our older citizens. Now finally
column13: with regard to the whole problem of combating recession
column14: as you call it
column15: we must use the full resources of the government in these respects: one
column16: we must see to it that credit is expanded as we go into any recessionary period - and understand
column17: I do not believe we're going into a recession. I believe this economy is sound and that we're going to move up. But second
column18: in addition to that
column19: if we do get into a recessionary period we should move on that part of the economy which is represented by the private sector
column20: and I mean stimulate that part of the economy that can create jobs - the private sector of the economy. This means through tax reform and if necessary tax cuts that will stimulate more jobs. I favor that rather than massive federal spending programs which will come into effect usually long after you've passed through the recessionary period. So we must use all of these weapons for the purpose of combating recession if it should come. But I do not expect it to come.

column1: Well Mr. Nixon has stated the record inaccurately in regard to the depressed area bill. I'm very familiar with it. It came out of the committee of which I was the chairman - the labor subcommittee - in fifty-five. I was the floor manager. We passed an area redevelopment bill far more effective than the bill the Administration suggested
column2: on two occasions
column3: and the President vetoed it both times. We passed a bill again this year in the cong- in the Senate and it died in the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives. Let me make it very clear that the bill that Mr. Nixon talked about did not mention Wilkes-Barre or Scranton; it did not mention West Virginia. Our bill was far more effective. The bill introduced and erd- sponsored by Senator Douglas was far more effective in trying to stimulate the economy of those areas. Secondly
column4: he has mentioned the problem of our older citizens. I cannot still understand why this Administration and Mr. Nixon oppose putting medical care for the aged under Social Security to give them some security. Third
column5: I believe we should step up the use of our surplus foods in these areas until we're able to get the people back to work. Five cents a day - that's what the food package averages per person. Fourthly
column6: I believe we should not carry out a hard money
column7: high interest rate policy which helped intensify certainly the recession of 1958
column8: and I think helped bring the slow-down of 1960. If we move into a recession in sixty-one
column9: then I would agree that we have to put more money into the economy
column10: and it can be done by either one of the two methods discussed. One is by ex- the programs such as aid to education. The other would be to make a judgment on what's the most effective tax program to stimulate our economy.

column4: one by Senator Kennedy and members of his party. Now the bill that the President had submitted would have provided more aid for those areas that really need it - areas like Scranton and Wilkes-Barre and the areas of West Virginia - than the ones that Senator Kennedy was supporting. On the other hand we found that the bill got into the legislative difficulties and consequently no action was taken. So point one
column5: at the highest priority we must get a bill for depressed areas through the next Congress. I have made recommendations on that and I have discussed them previously and I will spell them out further in the campaign. Second
column6: as we consider this problem of unemployment
column7: we have to realize where it is. In analyzing the figures we will find that our unemployment exists among the older citizens; it exists also among those who are inadequately trained; that is
column8: those who do not have an adequate opportunity for education. It also exists among minority groups. If we're going to combat unemployment
column9: then
column10: we have to do a better job in these areas. That's why I have a program for education
column11: a program in the case of equal job opportunities
column12: and one that would also deal with our older citizens. Now finally
column13: with regard to the whole problem of combating recession
column14: as you call it
column15: we must use the full resources of the government in these respects: one
column16: we must see to it that credit is expanded as we go into any recessionary period - and understand
column17: I do not believe we're going into a recession. I believe this economy is sound and that we're going to move up. But second
column18: in addition to that
column19: if we do get into a recessionary period we should move on that part of the economy which is represented by the private sector
column20: and I mean stimulate that part of the economy that can create jobs - the private sector of the economy. This means through tax reform and if necessary tax cuts that will stimulate more jobs. I favor that rather than massive federal spending programs which will come into effect usually long after you've passed through the recessionary period. So we must use all of these weapons for the purpose of combating recession if it should come. But I do not expect it to come.

column1: Well Mr. Nixon has stated the record inaccurately in regard to the depressed area bill. I'm very familiar with it. It came out of the committee of which I was the chairman - the labor subcommittee - in fifty-five. I was the floor manager. We passed an area redevelopment bill far more effective than the bill the Administration suggested
column2: on two occasions
column3: and the President vetoed it both times. We passed a bill again this year in the cong- in the Senate and it died in the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives. Let me make it very clear that the bill that Mr. Nixon talked about did not mention Wilkes-Barre or Scranton; it did not mention West Virginia. Our bill was far more effective. The bill introduced and erd- sponsored by Senator Douglas was far more effective in trying to stimulate the economy of those areas. Secondly
column4: he has mentioned the problem of our older citizens. I cannot still understand why this Administration and Mr. Nixon oppose putting medical care for the aged under Social Security to give them some security. Third
column5: I believe we should step up the use of our surplus foods in these areas until we're able to get the people back to work. Five cents a day - that's what the food package averages per person. Fourthly
column6: I believe we should not carry out a hard money
column7: high interest rate policy which helped intensify certainly the recession of 1958
column8: and I think helped bring the slow-down of 1960. If we move into a recession in sixty-one
column9: then I would agree that we have to put more money into the economy
column10: and it can be done by either one of the two methods discussed. One is by ex- the programs such as aid to education. The other would be to make a judgment on what's the most effective tax program to stimulate our economy.

of the economy', 'This means through tax reform and if necessary tax cuts that will stimulate more jobs', 'I favor that rather than massive federal spending programs which will come into effect usually long after youve passed through the recessionary period', 'So we must use all of these weapons for the purpose of combating recession if it should come', 'But I do not expect it to come', 'Well Mr Nixon has stated the record inaccurately in regard to the depressed area bill', 'Im very familiar with it', 'It came out of the committee of which I was the chairman  the labor subcommittee  in fiftyfive', 'I was the floor manager', 'We passed an area redevelopment bill far more effective than the bill the Administration suggested, on two occasions, and the President vetoed it both times', 'We passed a bill again this year in the cong in the Senate and it died in the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives', 'Let me make it very clear that the bill that Mr Nixon talked about did not mention WilkesBarre or Scranton; it did not mention West Virginia', 'Our bill was far more effective', 'The bill introduced and erd sponsored by Senator Douglas was far more effective in trying to stimulate the economy of those areas', 'Secondly, he has mentioned the problem of our older citizens', 'I cannot still understand why this Administration and Mr Nixon oppose putting medical care for the aged under Social Security to give them some security', 'Third, I believe we should step up the use of our surplus foods in these areas until were able to get the people back to work', 'Five cents a day  thats what the food package averages per person', 'Fourthly, I believe we should not carry out a hard money, high interest rate policy which helped intensify certainly the recession of 1958, and I think helped bring the slowdown of 1960', 'If we move into a recession in sixtyone, then I would agree that we have to put more money into the economy, and it can be done by either one of the two methods discussed', 'One is by ex the programs such as aid to education', 'The other would be to make a judgment on whats the most effective tax program to stimulate our economy']	['To combat unemployment we first must concentrate on the very areas to which you refer - the so-called depressed areas.'
column2: 'Now in the last Congress - the special session of the Congress - there was a bill: one by the President
column3: one by Senator Kennedy and members of his party.'
column4: 'Now the bill that the President had submitted would have provided more aid for those areas that really need it - areas like Scranton and Wilkes-Barre and the areas of West Virginia - than the ones that Senator Kennedy was supporting.'
column5: 'On the other hand we found that the bill got into the legislative difficulties and consequently no action was taken.'
column6: 'So point one
column7: at the highest priority we must get a bill for depressed areas through the next Congress.'
column8: 'I have made recommendations on that and I have discussed them previously and I will spell them out further in the campaign.'
column9: 'Second
column10: as we consider this problem of unemployment
column11: we have to realize where it is.'
column12: 'In analyzing the figures we will find that our unemployment exists among the older citizens; it exists also among those who are inadequately trained; that is
column13: those who do not have an adequate opportunity for education.'
column14: 'It also exists among minority groups.'
column15: ""If we're going to combat unemployment
column16: then
column17: we have to do a better job in these areas.""
column18: ""That's why I have a program for education
column19: a program in the case of equal job opportunities
column20: and one that would also deal with our older citizens.""
column21: ""Now finally
column22: with regard to the whole problem of combating recession
column23: as you call it
column24: we must use the full resources of the government in these respects: one
column25: we must see to it that credit is expanded as we go into any recessionary period - and understand
column26: I do not believe we're going into a recession.""
column27: ""I believe this economy is sound and that we're going to move up.""
column28: 'But second
column29: in addition to that
column30: if we do get into a recessionary period we should move on that part of the economy which is represented by the private sector
column31: and I mean stimulate that part of the economy that can create jobs - the private sector of the economy.'
column32: 'This means through tax reform and if necessary tax cuts that will stimulate more jobs.'
column33: ""I favor that rather than massive federal spending programs which will come into effect usually long after you've passed through the recessionary period.""
column34: 'So we must use all of these weapons for the purpose of combating recession if it should come.'
column35: 'But I do not expect it to come.'
column36: 'Well Mr. Nixon has stated the record inaccurately in regard to the depressed area bill.'
column38: 'It came out of the committee of which I was the chairman - the labor subcommittee - in fifty-five.'
column39: 'I was the floor manager.'
column40: 'We passed an area redevelopment bill far more effective than the bill the Administration suggested
column41: on two occasions
column42: and the President vetoed it both times.'
column43: 'We passed a bill again this year in the cong- in the Senate and it died in the Rules Committee of the House of Representatives.'
column44: 'Let me make it very clear that the bill that Mr. Nixon talked about did not mention Wilkes-Barre or Scranton; it did not mention West Virginia.'
column45: 'Our bill was far more effective.'
column46: 'The bill introduced and erd- sponsored by Senator Douglas was far more effective in trying to stimulate the economy of those areas.'
column47: 'Secondly
column48: he has mentioned the problem of our older citizens.'
column49: 'I cannot still understand why this Administration and Mr. Nixon oppose putting medical care for the aged under Social Security to give them some security.'
column50: ""Third
column51: I believe we should step up the use of our surplus foods in these areas until we're able to get the people back to work.""
column52: ""Five cents a day - that's what the food package averages per person.""
column53: 'Fourthly
column54: I believe we should not carry out a hard money
column55: high interest rate policy which helped intensify certainly the recession of 1958
column56: and I think helped bring the slow-down of 1960.'
column57: 'If we move into a recession in sixty-one
column58: then I would agree that we have to put more money into the economy
column59: and it can be done by either one of the two methods discussed.'
column60: 'One is by ex- the programs such as aid to education.'
column61: ""The other would be to make a judgment on what's the most effective tax program to stimulate our economy.""]"	1738.6	1989.48	['clip_39_0'

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 8)	" Well I understood that this was the Eisenhower-Nixon Administration according to all the Republican uh - propaganda that I've read. The question is what we're going to do in the future. I've been critical of this Administration and I've been critical of the President. In fact uh - Mr. Nixon uh - discussed that a week ago in a speech. I believe that our power and prestige in the last eight years has declined. Now what is the issue is what we're going to do in the future. Now that's an issue between Mr. Nixon and myself. He feels that we're moving ahead uh - in a - we're not going into a recession in this country
column4: economically; he feels that our power and prestige is stronger than it ever was relative to that of the Communists
column5: that we're moving ahead. I disagree. And I believe the American people have to make the choice on November eighth between the view of whether we have to move ahead faster
column6: whether what we're doing now is not satisfactory
column7: whether we have to build greater strength at home and abroad and Mr. Nixon's view. That's the great issue. President Eisenhower moves from the scene on January twentieth and the next four years are the critical years. And that's the debate. That's the argument between Mr. Nixon and myself and on that issue the American people have to make their judgment and I think it's a important judgment. I think in many ways this election is more important than any since 1932
column8: or certainly almost any in this century. Because we disagree very fundamentally on the position of the United States
column9: and if his view prevails then I think that's going to bring an important result to this country in the sixties. If our view prevails that we have to do more
column10: that we have to make a greater national and international effort
column11: that we have lost prestige in Latin America - the President of Brazil - the new incumbent running for office called on Castro during his campaign because he thought it was important to get the vote of those who were supporting Castro in Latin America. In Africa
column12: the United States has ignored Latin uh - Africa. We gave more scholarships to the Congo - this summer we offered them - than we've given to all of Africa the year before. Less than two hundred for all the countries of Africa and they need trained leadership more than anything. We've been uh - having a very clear decision in the last eight years. Mr. Nixon has been part of that Administration. He's had experience in it. And I believe this Administration has not met its responsibilities in the last eight years
column13: that our power relative to that of the Communists is declining
column14: that we're facing a very hazardous time in the sixties
column15: and unless the United States begin to move here - unless we start to go ahead - I don't believe that we're going to meet our responsibility to our own people or to the cause of freedom. I think the choice is clear and it involves the future.

column1: Well first of all
column2: I think Senator Kennedy should make up his mind with regard to my responsibility. In our first debate he indicated that I had not had experience or at least uh - had not participated significantly in the making of the decisions. I'm glad to hear tonight that he does suggest that I have had some experience. Let me make my position cl ear. I have participated in the discussions leading to the decisions in this Administration. I'm proud of the record of this Administration. I don't stand on it because it isn't something to stand on but something to build on. Now looking at Senator Kennedy's credentials: he is suggesting that he will move America faster and further than I will. But what does he offer? He offers retreads of programs that failed. I submit to you that as you look at his programs
column3: his program for example with regard to the Federal Reserve and uh - free money or loose money uh - high - low interest rates
column4: his program in the economic field generally are the programs that were adopted and tried during the Truman Administration. And when we compare the economic progress of this country in the Truman Administration with that of the Eisenhower Administration
column5: we find that in every index there has been a tr- great deal more performance and more progress in this Administration than in that one. I say the programs and the leadership that failed then is not the program and the leadership that America needs now. I say that the American people don't want to go back to those policies. And incidentally if Senator Kennedy disagrees
column6: he should indicate where he believes those policies are different from those he's advocating today.

And incidentally if Senator Kennedy disagrees
column6: he should indicate where he believes those policies are different from those he's advocating today.
