column2: '07Oct'
column3: 8)	" Well I understood that this was the Eisenhower-Nixon Administration according to all the Republican uh - propaganda that I've read. The question is what we're going to do in the future. I've been critical of this Administration and I've been critical of the President. In fact uh - Mr. Nixon uh - discussed that a week ago in a speech. I believe that our power and prestige in the last eight years has declined. Now what is the issue is what we're going to do in the future. Now that's an issue between Mr. Nixon and myself. He feels that we're moving ahead uh - in a - we're not going into a recession in this country
column4: economically; he feels that our power and prestige is stronger than it ever was relative to that of the Communists
column5: that we're moving ahead. I disagree. And I believe the American people have to make the choice on November eighth between the view of whether we have to move ahead faster
column6: whether what we're doing now is not satisfactory
column7: whether we have to build greater strength at home and abroad and Mr. Nixon's view. That's the great issue. President Eisenhower moves from the scene on January twentieth and the next four years are the critical years. And that's the debate. That's the argument between Mr. Nixon and myself and on that issue the American people have to make their judgment and I think it's a important judgment. I think in many ways this election is more important than any since 1932
column8: or certainly almost any in this century. Because we disagree very fundamentally on the position of the United States
column9: and if his view prevails then I think that's going to bring an important result to this country in the sixties. If our view prevails that we have to do more
column10: that we have to make a greater national and international effort
column11: that we have lost prestige in Latin America - the President of Brazil - the new incumbent running for office called on Castro during his campaign because he thought it was important to get the vote of those who were supporting Castro in Latin America. In Africa
column12: the United States has ignored Latin uh - Africa. We gave more scholarships to the Congo - this summer we offered them - than we've given to all of Africa the year before. Less than two hundred for all the countries of Africa and they need trained leadership more than anything. We've been uh - having a very clear decision in the last eight years. Mr. Nixon has been part of that Administration. He's had experience in it. And I believe this Administration has not met its responsibilities in the last eight years
column13: that our power relative to that of the Communists is declining
column14: that we're facing a very hazardous time in the sixties
column15: and unless the United States begin to move here - unless we start to go ahead - I don't believe that we're going to meet our responsibility to our own people or to the cause of freedom. I think the choice is clear and it involves the future.

column1: Well first of all
column2: I think Senator Kennedy should make up his mind with regard to my responsibility. In our first debate he indicated that I had not had experience or at least uh - had not participated significantly in the making of the decisions. I'm glad to hear tonight that he does suggest that I have had some experience. Let me make my position cl ear. I have participated in the discussions leading to the decisions in this Administration. I'm proud of the record of this Administration. I don't stand on it because it isn't something to stand on but something to build on. Now looking at Senator Kennedy's credentials: he is suggesting that he will move America faster and further than I will. But what does he offer? He offers retreads of programs that failed. I submit to you that as you look at his programs
column3: his program for example with regard to the Federal Reserve and uh - free money or loose money uh - high - low interest rates
column4: his program in the economic field generally are the programs that were adopted and tried during the Truman Administration. And when we compare the economic progress of this country in the Truman Administration with that of the Eisenhower Administration
column5: we find that in every index there has been a tr- great deal more performance and more progress in this Administration than in that one. I say the programs and the leadership that failed then is not the program and the leadership that America needs now. I say that the American people don't want to go back to those policies. And incidentally if Senator Kennedy disagrees
column6: he should indicate where he believes those policies are different from those he's advocating today.

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 8)	" Well I understood that this was the Eisenhower-Nixon Administration according to all the Republican uh - propaganda that I've read. The question is what we're going to do in the future. I've been critical of this Administration and I've been critical of the President. In fact uh - Mr. Nixon uh - discussed that a week ago in a speech. I believe that our power and prestige in the last eight years has declined. Now what is the issue is what we're going to do in the future. Now that's an issue between Mr. Nixon and myself. He feels that we're moving ahead uh - in a - we're not going into a recession in this country
column4: economically; he feels that our power and prestige is stronger than it ever was relative to that of the Communists
column5: that we're moving ahead. I disagree. And I believe the American people have to make the choice on November eighth between the view of whether we have to move ahead faster
column6: whether what we're doing now is not satisfactory
column7: whether we have to build greater strength at home and abroad and Mr. Nixon's view. That's the great issue. President Eisenhower moves from the scene on January twentieth and the next four years are the critical years. And that's the debate. That's the argument between Mr. Nixon and myself and on that issue the American people have to make their judgment and I think it's a important judgment. I think in many ways this election is more important than any since 1932
column8: or certainly almost any in this century. Because we disagree very fundamentally on the position of the United States
column9: and if his view prevails then I think that's going to bring an important result to this country in the sixties. If our view prevails that we have to do more
column10: that we have to make a greater national and international effort
column11: that we have lost prestige in Latin America - the President of Brazil - the new incumbent running for office called on Castro during his campaign because he thought it was important to get the vote of those who were supporting Castro in Latin America. In Africa
column12: the United States has ignored Latin uh - Africa. We gave more scholarships to the Congo - this summer we offered them - than we've given to all of Africa the year before. Less than two hundred for all the countries of Africa and they need trained leadership more than anything. We've been uh - having a very clear decision in the last eight years. Mr. Nixon has been part of that Administration. He's had experience in it. And I believe this Administration has not met its responsibilities in the last eight years
column13: that our power relative to that of the Communists is declining
column14: that we're facing a very hazardous time in the sixties
column15: and unless the United States begin to move here - unless we start to go ahead - I don't believe that we're going to meet our responsibility to our own people or to the cause of freedom. I think the choice is clear and it involves the future.

column1: Well first of all
column2: I think Senator Kennedy should make up his mind with regard to my responsibility. In our first debate he indicated that I had not had experience or at least uh - had not participated significantly in the making of the decisions. I'm glad to hear tonight that he does suggest that I have had some experience. Let me make my position cl ear. I have participated in the discussions leading to the decisions in this Administration. I'm proud of the record of this Administration. I don't stand on it because it isn't something to stand on but something to build on. Now looking at Senator Kennedy's credentials: he is suggesting that he will move America faster and further than I will. But what does he offer? He offers retreads of programs that failed. I submit to you that as you look at his programs
column3: his program for example with regard to the Federal Reserve and uh - free money or loose money uh - high - low interest rates
column4: his program in the economic field generally are the programs that were adopted and tried during the Truman Administration. And when we compare the economic progress of this country in the Truman Administration with that of the Eisenhower Administration
column5: we find that in every index there has been a tr- great deal more performance and more progress in this Administration than in that one. I say the programs and the leadership that failed then is not the program and the leadership that America needs now. I say that the American people don't want to go back to those policies. And incidentally if Senator Kennedy disagrees
column6: he should indicate where he believes those policies are different from those he's advocating today.

column18: ""That's the argument between Mr. Nixon and myself and on that issue the American people have to make their judgment and I think it's a important judgment.""
column19: 'I think in many ways this election is more important than any since 1932
column20: or certainly almost any in this century.'
column21: ""Because we disagree very fundamentally on the position of the United States
column22: and if his view prevails then I think that's going to bring an important result to this country in the sixties.""
column23: 'If our view prevails that we have to do more
column24: that we have to make a greater national and international effort
column25: that we have lost prestige in Latin America - the President of Brazil - the new incumbent running for office called on Castro during his campaign because he thought it was important to get the vote of those who were supporting Castro in Latin America.'
column26: 'In Africa
column27: the United States has ignored Latin uh - Africa.'
column28: ""We gave more scholarships to the Congo - this summer we offered them - than we've given to all of Africa the year before.""
column29: 'Less than two hundred for all the countries of Africa and they need trained leadership more than anything.'
column30: ""We've been uh - having a very clear decision in the last eight years.""
column31: 'Mr. Nixon has been part of that Administration.'
column32: ""He's had experience in it.""
column33: ""And I believe this Administration has not met its responsibilities in the last eight years
column34: that our power relative to that of the Communists is declining
column35: that we're facing a very hazardous time in the sixties
column36: and unless the United States begin to move here - unless we start to go ahead - I don't believe that we're going to meet our responsibility to our own people or to the cause of freedom.""
column37: 'I think the choice is clear and it involves the future.'
column38: 'Well first of all
column39: I think Senator Kennedy should make up his mind with regard to my responsibility.'
column40: 'In our first debate he indicated that I had not had experience or at least uh - had not participated significantly in the making of the decisions.'
column41: ""I'm glad to hear tonight that he does suggest that I have had some experience.""
column42: 'Let me make my position cl ear.'
column43: 'I have participated in the discussions leading to the decisions in this Administration.'
column44: ""I'm proud of the record of this Administration.""
column45: ""I don't stand on it because it isn't something to stand on but something to build on.""
column46: ""Now looking at Senator Kennedy's credentials: he is suggesting that he will move America faster and further than I will.""
column47: 'But what does he offer?'
column48: 'He offers retreads of programs that failed.'
column49: 'I submit to you that as you look at his programs
column50: his program for example with regard to the Federal Reserve and uh - free money or loose money uh - high - low interest rates
column51: his program in the economic field generally are the programs that were adopted and tried during the Truman Administration.'
column52: 'And when we compare the economic progress of this country in the Truman Administration with that of the Eisenhower Administration
column53: we find that in every index there has been a tr- great deal more performance and more progress in this Administration than in that one.'
column54: 'I say the programs and the leadership that failed then is not the program and the leadership that America needs now.'
column55: ""I say that the American people don't want to go back to those policies.""
column56: ""And incidentally if Senator Kennedy disagrees

column2: '07Oct'
column3: 9)	" No
column4: of course I haven't talked to Prime Minister Macmillan. It would not be appropriate for me to do so. The President is still going to be president for the next four months and he
column5: of course
column6: is the only one who could commit this country in this period. As far as a summit conference is concerned
column7: I want to make my position absolutely clear. I would be willing as president to meet with Mr. Khrushchev or any other world leader if it would serve the cause of peace. I would not be able wou- would be willing to meet with him however
column8: unless there were preparations for that conference which would give us some reasonable certainty - some reasonable certainty - that you were going to have some success. We must not build up the hopes of the world and then dash them as was the case in Paris. There
column9: Mr. Khrushchev came to that conference determined to break it up. He was going to break it up because he would - knew that he wasn't going to get his way on Berlin and on the other key matters with which he was concerned at the Paris Conference. Now
column10: if we're going to have another summit conference
column11: there must be negotiations at the diplomatic level - the ambassadors
column12: the Secretaries of State
column13: and others at that level - prior to that time
column14: which will delineate the issues and which will prepare the way for the heads of state to meet and make some progress. Otherwise
column15: if we find the heads of state meeting and not making progress
column16: we will find that the cause of peace will have been hurt rather than helped. So under these circumstances
column17: I
column18: therefore
column19: strongly urge and I will strongly hold
column20: if I have the opportunity to urge or to hold - this position: that any summit conference would be gone into only after the most careful preparation and only after Mr. Khrushchev - after his disgraceful conduct at Paris
column21: after his disgraceful conduct at the United Nations - gave some assurance that he really wanted to sit down and talk and to accomplish something and not just to make propaganda.

column1: I have no disagreement with the Vice President's position on that. It - my view is the same as his. Let me say there is only one uh - point I would add. That before we go into the summit
column2: before we ever meet again
column3: I think it's important that the United States build its strength; that it build its military strength as well as its own economic strength. If we negotiate from a position where the power balance or wave is moving away from us
column4: it's extremely difficult to reach a successful decision on Berlin as well as the other questions. Now the next president of the United States in his first year is going to be confronted with a very serious question on our defense of Berlin
column5: our commitment to Berlin. It's going to be a test of our nerve and will. It's going to be a test of our strength. And because we're going to move in sixty-one and two
column6: partly because we have not maintained our strength with sufficient vigor in the last years
column7: I believe that before we meet that crisis
column8: that the next president of the United States should send a message to Congress asking for a revitalization of our military strength
column9: because come spring or late in the winter we're going to be face to face with the most serious Berlin crisis since l949 or fifty. On the question of the summit
column10: I agree with the position of Mr. Nixon. I would not meet Mr. Khrushchev unless there were some agreements at the secondary level - foreign ministers or ambassadors - which would indicate that the meeting would have some hope of success
column11: or a useful exchange of ideas.
